case_title: Ch. MUHAMMAD SADIQ vs MUMTAZ ALI AND ANOTHER

accussed_details.name: Mumtaz Ali
allegation: Failure to pay transfer price of plot

complaint_summary: Petitioner challenged the order of Deputy Settlement Commissioner dated 11th May 1974, alleging improper service of statutory notice regarding transfer price payment for a plot of land.
investigation_summary: Deputy Settlement Commissioner conducted inquiries into the disputed service of notice. Comparison of signatures and procedural irregularities were examined. Findings indicated no statutory notice was served on Respondent No. 1.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the petition, ruling that the statutory notice was not served on Respondent No. 1 as required under the Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1958. The court upheld the findings of the Deputy Settlement Commissioner and deemed the impugned order lawful and proper.
legal_arguments: Violation of principles of natural justice due to denial of examination of clerk and handwriting expert.
Failure to comply with court directions for proper inquiry into statutory notice service.
sections: Paragraphs 22 and 24 of the Schedule to the Displaced Persons Act

witness_statement.Deputy Settlement Commissioner: Confirmed no statutory notice was served on Respondent No. 1.

maxims.Natural Justice: Audi alteram partem (hear the other side)

legal_terms.Statutory Notice: A notice required by law to be served in a prescribed manner.

words_and_phrases.Demand Notice: A formal notice requiring payment or compliance within a specified time.

summary_vector_notes: Petition dismissed due to lack of statutory notice service and procedural irregularities in property transfer. Court upheld findings of Deputy Settlement Commissioner.
